article:
In macroeconomics, 'real rigidities' are real prices and wages that fail to
adjust to the level indicated by equilibrium or if something holds one price or
wage fixed to a relative value of another. Snowdon and Vane, 365. Real
rigidities can be distinguished from nominal rigidities, rigidities that do not
adjust because prices can be sticky and fail to change value even as the
underlying factors that determine prices fluctuate. Snowdon and Vane,
365. Real rigidities, along with nominal, are a key part of new Keynesian
economics. Snowdon and Vane, 378. Economic models with real rigidities
lead to nominal shocks (like changes in monetary policy) having a large impact
on the economy. Snowdon and Vane, 379.
headings: Real rigidities in the product market
Real rigidities in the labor market
